column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=Lobsters and Crabs , though exceedingly different in
#Text=figure, have propensities and habits of great similarity.
#Text=They annually cast their shells, and obtain new ones,
#Text=completely hardened, in little more than forty-eight
#Text=hours.
#Text=They are extremely fierce and voracious, but
#Text=when they chance to lose a limb in their frequent combats, it is completely renewed in about three weeks.
#Text=If a lobster be new, it has a pleasant scent at that
#Text=part of the tail which joins to the body, and the tail
#Text=will, when opened, fall smart, like a spring; but when
#Text=stale, it has a rank scent, and the tail limber and flagging.
#Text=If it be spent, a white scurf will issue from the
#Text=mouth and roots of the small legs.
#Text=If it be full, the
#Text=tail, about the middle, will be full of hard reddish
#Text=skinned meat, which you may discover by thrusting a
#Text=knife between the joints, on the bend of the tail.
#Text=The
#Text=heaviest are best, if there be no water in them.
#Text=The
#Text=cock is generally smaller than the hen, of a deeper
#Text=red when boiled, has no spawn or seed under its tail,
#Text=and the uppermost fins within its tail are stiff and
#Text=hard.
#Text=Lobsters are in season during the summer months.
#Text=Cray Fish — should be chosen by the same rules as
#Text=lobsters.
#Text=Crabs . — The heaviest are best, whether small or
#Text=large, and those of a middling size are sweetest.
#Text=If
#Text=light they are watery ; when in perfection the joints of
#Text=the legs are stiff, and the body has a very agreeable
#Text=smell.
#Text=The eyes look dead and loose when stale.
#Text=Prawns and Shrimps , if they are hard and stiff, of a
#Text=pleasant scent, and their tails turned strongly inward,
#Text=are new ; but if they are limber, their colour faded, of
#Text=a faint smell, and feel slimy, they are stale.
#Text=Oysters . — The oysters of this country are unlike
#Text=those of some others ; a single one of which, it has
#Text=been said, will serve several persons for a meal.
#Text=With
#Text=us, the smallest kinds, particularly those termed Natives, which come into season rather later than the
#Text=others, are generally the sweetest.
#Text=For eating raw,
#Text=the native is indeed preferable to all others.
#Text=The
#Text=rock oyster is the largest, and suits admirably for
#Text=stewing, &c. ; but if eaten raw, it usually has a coarse
#Text=and strong flavour.
